Subject: Re: [cantera] Getting gas composition out of the flame object?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=44728387; y=lnm-WsRaT72OhU5lWEx3ZQQme_mEfSHwSusTv0JJ7wCz
X-Yahoo-Profile: dggoodwin

It is simple.

If you are using Python, do this:

If you have an object of class "BurnerFlame" (call it "b"), then

  b.gas returns the gas object used for the flame.

To set the gas object to the state at grid point "j", do this:

b.setGasState(j)

Then you can access mole fractions, etc., by commands like:

x = b.gas.moleFraction()
T = b.gas.temperature()

etc.

There is documentation that explains this. All you have to do in  
Python is import the module you want help on:

 >>> from Cantera.OneD import BurnerFlame

and then type:

 >>> help(BurnerFlame)

If you are using MATLAB, it is not as easy, simply because the MATLAB  
Cantera interface is not as fully developed as the Python interface.   
I would recommend running flame simulations from Python for this reason.

Dave


On Apr 23, 2007, at 11:41 PM, pavelyar wrote:

> Hello everybody,
>
> Could anyone please explain me how I can extract a gas composition out
> of a flame object?
>
> I have a flate flame burner solved for my conditions. Now I want to
> model the hot products reacting on a Pt surface.
>
> Can I extract the hot products composition at some axial distance so
> that I could use those to create another gas object that will react on
> a catalytic surface (just like CH4/air mixture reacts in the catcomb
> demo)?
>
> Thanks a lot
>
> Pavel
